stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Backdoor Network Activity Discovered on Compromised Hosts
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
Between 29 October 2014 and 24 November 2014 it was observed that at least fourteen separate hosts were infected with the same malware (backdoor) attempting to communicate with a C2 server at the IP address 81.91.144.234.
It is unknown how the initial compromise occurred on the victim network or how long the intruders have had access to the network.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
It was reported that the IP address the malware called out to was a probable proxy server. The IP address was registered to Datak ADSL Service, Karaj.
The command and control IP address has mainly hosted what appear to be mail servers according to PDNS results:
NAME IP FIRSTSEEN LASTSEEN ns2.kalleh.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.atibal.com. 81.91.144.234 thr0018.solico-group.com. 81.91.144.234 mail.solico-tehran.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.rasatop.com. 81.91.144.234 iranbartar.ir. 81.91.144.234 smtp.solico-tehran.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.kalleh-meat.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.kalleh-pemina.com. 81.91.144.234 smtp.topsolico.com. 81.91.144.234
According to the report, the malware in this malware family typically listen for C2 on inbound TCP port 443.
Hash values for the malware files from this report were not provided. However, the following import hashes may be used to identify this and related malware.
import hash a565e8c853b8325ad98f1fac9c40fb88 import hash ED7A9C6D9FC664AFE2DE2DD165A9338C import hash 734740B16053CCC555686814A93DFBEB
import hash 734740B16053CCC555686814A93DFBEB This file is a dropper that installs the other two files.
import hash ED7A9C6D9FC664AFE2DE2DD165A9338C This file is a custom coded backdoor. Observed functionalities include the ability to fingerprint the victim machine, run remote commands, perform directory listings, perform process listings, and transfer files.
import hash a565e8c853b8325ad98f1fac9c40fb88 This file is custom coded malware with basic backdoor functionality. Observed functionalities include the ability to fingerprint the victim machine, run remote commands, perform directory listings, perform process listings, and transfer files.
Malware in this family are typically loaded via a dropper, installed as a service, and listen on TCP port 443. The backdoor may have an associated configuration file which can contain a configurable port. No configuration file was observed in these fourteen particular instances of infection.
The filenames and service names associated with this malware are configurable and differ per victim, however similar files may be detected by using the YARA rule included below.
strings: $str1 = {8A 04 17 8B FB 34 A7 46 88 02 83 C9 FF} condition: (uint16(0) == 0x4D5A) and $str1
